title: Romans Chapter 7 Quiz - Multi-Level
description: An enhanced quiz on Romans chapter 7 with Easy, Medium, Hard, and Theological levels. Each level has 15 carefully crafted questions. Choose your difficulty and dive in!

easy.title: Romans Chapter 7 Quiz - Easy Level
easy.description: Perfect for beginners! Test your basic knowledge of Romans Chapter 7.

questions.question: According to Romans 7:1, how long does the law have dominion over a man?
questions.correctAnswer: As long as he liveth
questions.explanation: Romans 7:1 states that the law hath dominion over a man as long as he liveth.

questions.question: In Romans 7:3, what is a woman called if she is married to another man while her husband is still alive?
questions.correctAnswer: Adulteress
questions.explanation: Romans 7:3 explains that if a woman is married to another man while her husband liveth, she shall be called an adulteress.

questions.question: Romans 7:4 says believers are dead to the law by what means?
questions.correctAnswer: By the body of Christ
questions.explanation: Romans 7:4 states that believers have become dead to the law by the body of Christ.

questions.question: According to Romans 7:6, what kind of service should believers now render?
questions.correctAnswer: In newness of spirit
questions.explanation: Romans 7:6 says believers should serve in newness of spirit, not the oldness of the letter.

questions.question: True or False: Romans 7:7 says that the law itself is sin.
questions.correctAnswer: False
questions.explanation: Romans 7:7 clearly says, 'Is the law sin? God forbid,' indicating the law is not sin.

questions.question: According to Romans 7:8, what did sin do by taking occasion through the commandment?
questions.correctAnswer: Wrought all manner of concupiscence
questions.explanation: Romans 7:8 states that sin, taking occasion by the commandment, wrought in Paul all manner of concupiscence.

questions.question: What does Romans 7:9 say happened when the commandment came?
questions.correctAnswer: Sin revived, and I died
questions.explanation: Romans 7:9 explains that when the commandment came, sin revived, and Paul died.

questions.question: True or False: Romans 7:12 describes the law and the commandment as holy, just, and good.
questions.correctAnswer: True
questions.explanation: Romans 7:12 states that the law is holy, and the commandment holy, and just, and good.

questions.question: Fill in the blank from Romans 7:14: 'For we know that the law is ______: but I am carnal, sold under sin.'
questions.correctAnswer: spiritual
questions.explanation: Romans 7:14 says the law is spiritual, contrasting with the carnal nature of the speaker.

questions.question: According to Romans 7:15, what does Paul say about what he does versus what he would do?
options: He does not do what he would, but does what he hates
He always does what he wants
questions.correctAnswer: He does not do what he would, but does what he hates
questions.explanation: Romans 7:15 states Paul does not do what he would, but what he hates, he does.

questions.question: Romans 7:17 says who dwelleth in Paul and causes him to do what he does?
questions.correctAnswer: Sin
questions.explanation: Romans 7:17 states that sin dwelleth in Paul, causing him to do the things he does.

questions.question: What does Romans 7:18 say dwelleth in Paul’s flesh?
questions.correctAnswer: No good thing
questions.explanation: Romans 7:18 states that in Paul's flesh dwelleth no good thing.

questions.question: True or False: Romans 7:21 says when Paul wants to do good, evil is present with him.
questions.correctAnswer: True
questions.explanation: Romans 7:21 clearly states that when Paul would do good, evil is present with him.

questions.question: According to Romans 7:22, in what does Paul delight?
options: The law of God after the inward man
questions.correctAnswer: The law of God after the inward man
questions.explanation: Romans 7:22 says Paul delights in the law of God after the inward man.

questions.question: According to Romans 7:24, who does Paul ask to deliver him from the body of this death?
questions.correctAnswer: Who shall deliver me?
questions.explanation: Romans 7:24 has Paul asking, 'O wretched man that I am! who shall deliver me from the body of this death?'

medium.title: Romans Chapter 7 Quiz - Medium Level
medium.description: Ready for more? Apply biblical truths from Romans Chapter 7 to real-life situations.

questions.question: A fellow believer struggles with obeying God's law and feels defeated by sin. Based on Romans 7, what biblical truth would you share about the nature of the law and sin?
options: The law itself is sinful and causes death
The law is holy and good, but sin uses the law to produce death
Sin is not related to the law at all
Obedience to the law guarantees freedom from sin
questions.correctAnswer: The law is holy and good, but sin uses the law to produce death
questions.explanation: Romans 7:12 states the law is holy, just, and good. Romans 7:13 explains sin works death through what is good (the law). Romans 7:11 says sin deceived and killed through the commandment.

questions.question: How does Romans 7:4 teach us about our relationship to the law through Christ regarding fruitfulness in the Christian life?
options: We remain under the law to produce fruit
We die to the law by Christ's body to be married to Him and bear fruit for God
The law is abolished and irrelevant to fruitfulness
Fruitfulness comes only from self-effort apart from the law
questions.correctAnswer: We die to the law by Christ's body to be married to Him and bear fruit for God
questions.explanation: Romans 7:4 says believers are dead to the law through Christ's body so they can be joined to Him and bring forth fruit unto God.

questions.question: A believer is confused if the law is sinful because it reveals sin. What does Romans 7 say about this?
options: The law is sin because it exposes sin
The law is not sin but reveals sin and its nature
The law is powerless against sin
questions.correctAnswer: The law is not sin but reveals sin and its nature
questions.explanation: Romans 7:7 clarifies that the law is not sin, but reveals sin (e.g., lust through the command 'Thou shalt not covet'). Romans 7:8 shows sin uses the commandment to produce concupiscence.

questions.question: According to Romans 7, what happens to a believer's service toward God after being delivered from the law?
options: They serve in the oldness of the letter
They serve in newness of the spirit
They no longer need to serve
They serve by strict adherence to law
questions.correctAnswer: They serve in newness of the spirit
questions.explanation: Romans 7:6 teaches believers are delivered from the law to serve in newness of spirit, not the old letter of the law.

questions.question: A believer feels trapped by sin in their daily actions. What does Romans 7 teach about this inner conflict?
options: The believer has no conflict once saved
There is a war between the law of the mind and the law of sin in the body
Sin no longer dwells in the believer
The flesh always wins over the spirit
questions.correctAnswer: There is a war between the law of the mind and the law of sin in the body
questions.explanation: Romans 7:23 describes a conflict where another law in the members wars against the law of the mind, bringing captivity to sin.

questions.question: How does Romans 7 describe the believer's struggle when they want to do good but fail?
options: They always succeed in doing good
They do the evil they do not want and fail to do the good they desire
They do not desire to do good
They are free from any wrongdoing
questions.correctAnswer: They do the evil they do not want and fail to do the good they desire
questions.explanation: Romans 7:19 states the believer does not do the good they want but does the evil they do not want.

questions.question: What is the source of the sinful actions that a believer struggles with, according to Romans 7?
options: Sin that dwells within the believer
questions.correctAnswer: Sin that dwells within the believer
questions.explanation: Romans 7:17 and 7:20 explain that when the believer does what they would not, it is sin dwelling in them, not the true self.

questions.question: A believer expresses frustration and cries out for deliverance from sin. What is the biblical response according to Romans 7?
options: There is no deliverance from sin
Deliverance comes through Jesus Christ our Lord
Deliverance comes only through stricter law-keeping
Deliverance is found in isolation from the world
questions.correctAnswer: Deliverance comes through Jesus Christ our Lord
questions.explanation: Romans 7:24-25 records the cry for deliverance and the thanksgiving to God through Jesus Christ as the answer.

questions.question: According to Romans 7:1-3, how does the law relate to marriage and the bond between husband and wife?
options: The law binds a wife to her husband only while he lives
A wife is free to marry another even if the husband is alive
Marriage is not affected by the law
The law binds the wife to her husband forever
questions.correctAnswer: The law binds a wife to her husband only while he lives
questions.explanation: Romans 7:1-3 explains a woman is bound by law to her husband while he lives, but if he dies, she is free to marry another without being an adulteress.

questions.question: True or False: Romans 7 states that without the law, sin is inactive and powerless.
questions.correctAnswer: True
questions.explanation: Romans 7:8 states that without the law, sin was dead, showing sin is inactive without the law's commandment.

questions.question: True or False: According to Romans 7, the law is made responsible for the death and suffering of the believer.
questions.correctAnswer: False
questions.explanation: Romans 7:13 clarifies that the law itself was not made death to the believer; rather sin used the law to produce death, so the law remains good.

questions.question: Fill in the blank: Romans 7 teaches that the law is __________; but I am carnal, sold under sin.
questions.correctAnswer: spiritual
questions.explanation: Romans 7:14 explicitly states the law is spiritual, contrasting with the believer's fleshly nature.

questions.question: How does Romans 7:22 describe the believer's attitude toward God's law despite the struggle with sin?
options: The believer hates the law of God
The believer delights in the law of God inwardly
The believer is indifferent to the law
questions.correctAnswer: The believer delights in the law of God inwardly
questions.explanation: Romans 7:22 states the inward man delights in God's law, showing love and desire for God's will despite outward struggle.

questions.question: What does Romans 7:5 say was the effect of the law on the believer when they were 'in the flesh'?
options: The motions of sin worked through the law to produce death
The law brought life and peace
questions.correctAnswer: The motions of sin worked through the law to produce death
questions.explanation: Romans 7:5 explains that while in the flesh, sin's motions, stirred up by the law, worked in members to bring forth fruit unto death.

questions.question: According to Romans 7:15-16, how does the believer respond to actions they do not want to perform?
options: They approve those actions as good
They are unaware of those actions
They perform those actions without regret
questions.correctAnswer: They approve those actions as good
questions.explanation: Romans 7:15-16 show the believer does not approve what they do, but when they do what they would not, they consent that the law is good.

hard.title: Romans Chapter 7 Quiz - Hard Level
hard.description: Challenge yourself with deep analysis and cross-biblical connections from Romans Chapter 7.

questions.question: In Romans 7:1-3, Paul uses the example of a married woman to illustrate which theological principle concerning the law?
options: The law has dominion over a person only as long as they live
The law is abolished with the coming of Christ
The law applies only to men
Marriage is a symbol of sin
questions.correctAnswer: The law has dominion over a person only as long as they live
questions.explanation: Romans 7:1-3 explains that a woman is bound to her husband by law as long as he lives, illustrating that the law's authority lasts as long as the person lives.

questions.question: What does Paul mean when he says believers have 'become dead to the law by the body of Christ' in Romans 7:4?
options: Believers are freed from the law's condemnation through Christ's death
Believers no longer need to follow any moral laws
The law is replaced by Gentile customs
questions.correctAnswer: Believers are freed from the law's condemnation through Christ's death
questions.explanation: Romans 7:4 uses the analogy of death to explain that through Christ's death, believers are released from the law's binding authority to bring forth fruit unto God.

questions.question: According to Romans 7:5-6, what contrast does Paul draw between serving under the law and serving in newness of spirit?
options: Serving under the law brings death, but serving in newness of spirit brings life
Serving under the law is easier than serving in newness of spirit
Serving under the law is only for Jews, newness of spirit for Gentiles
Serving under the law is more spiritual than serving in newness of spirit
questions.correctAnswer: Serving under the law brings death, but serving in newness of spirit brings life
questions.explanation: Romans 7:5-6 contrasts the 'motions of sins' producing death under the law with the newness of spirit believers enjoy after being delivered from the law.

questions.question: In Romans 7:7, Paul states that he had not known lust except through the law. What is the significance of this statement in relation to the law's role?
options: The law reveals sin by defining it
questions.correctAnswer: The law reveals sin by defining it
questions.explanation: Romans 7:7 clarifies that the law is not sin but reveals sin by defining what constitutes sinful behavior, such as coveting.

questions.question: How does Paul describe the effect of sin 'taking occasion by the commandment' in Romans 7:8?
options: Sin worked in him all manner of concupiscence
Sin was eliminated by the commandment
questions.correctAnswer: Sin worked in him all manner of concupiscence
questions.explanation: Romans 7:8 explains that sin exploits the commandment to provoke sinful desires, illustrating sin's deceptive power.

questions.question: What paradox does Paul highlight about the commandment in Romans 7:10?
options: The commandment was ordained to life but resulted in death
The commandment was harmful and sinful
The commandment was irrelevant to sin
questions.correctAnswer: The commandment was ordained to life but resulted in death
questions.explanation: Romans 7:10 states that although the commandment was meant to bring life, it paradoxically brought death due to sin exploiting it.

questions.question: Which description best fits the law according to Romans 7:12?
questions.correctAnswer: Holy, just, and good
questions.explanation: Romans 7:12 affirms that the law and the commandment are holy, just, and good, emphasizing the law's divine and moral nature.

questions.question: How does Paul describe himself in relation to the law and sin in Romans 7:14?
options: Carnal, sold under sin, though the law is spiritual
Spiritually perfect and free from sin
questions.correctAnswer: Carnal, sold under sin, though the law is spiritual
questions.explanation: Romans 7:14 contrasts the spiritual nature of the law with Paul's own carnal state, sold under sin, highlighting human weakness.

questions.question: In Romans 7:15, Paul expresses a struggle within himself. What is the nature of this internal conflict?
options: He does not do what he wants but does what he hates
He always does what he wants
questions.correctAnswer: He does not do what he wants but does what he hates
questions.explanation: Romans 7:15 describes Paul’s internal struggle where he fails to do the good he desires and instead does the evil he hates.

questions.question: According to Romans 7:18, what does Paul say about the presence of good in his flesh?
options: No good thing dwells in his flesh
His flesh is enlightened by the law
questions.correctAnswer: No good thing dwells in his flesh
questions.explanation: Romans 7:18 states that in Paul's flesh there is no good thing, although the will to do good is present, illustrating human inability to fully obey the law.

questions.question: What does Paul mean by 'another law in my members, warring against the law of my mind' in Romans 7:23?
options: The internal conflict between sinful nature and desire to obey God
The conflict between Jewish and Gentile laws
The law of Moses versus Roman law
The conflict between physical and spiritual laws
questions.correctAnswer: The internal conflict between sinful nature and desire to obey God
questions.explanation: Romans 7:23 describes the struggle between the flesh's sinful desires and the mind's allegiance to God's law, representing spiritual warfare within believers.

questions.question: What is the 'body of this death' from which Paul seeks deliverance in Romans 7:24?
options: The sinful human nature enslaved by sin
questions.correctAnswer: The sinful human nature enslaved by sin
questions.explanation: Romans 7:24 expresses Paul’s anguish over being captive to sin in his mortal body, seeking deliverance from this spiritual death.

questions.question: In Romans 7:25, Paul thanks God through Jesus Christ. What does he say about how he serves with his mind and flesh?
options: With the mind he serves the law of God, but with the flesh the law of sin
With both mind and flesh he serves the law of God
With the mind he serves sin, with the flesh he serves God
He has no conflict between mind and flesh
questions.correctAnswer: With the mind he serves the law of God, but with the flesh the law of sin
questions.explanation: Romans 7:25 acknowledges the duality in Paul’s experience—his mind serves God’s law, but his flesh is subject to sin’s law.

questions.question: True or False: According to Romans 7:7, Paul claims that the law itself is sin.
questions.correctAnswer: False
questions.explanation: Romans 7:7 explicitly states 'Is the law sin? God forbid.' indicating that the law is not sin but reveals sin.

questions.question: Fill in the blank: Romans 7:22 says, 'For I delight in the law of God after the _______ man.'
questions.correctAnswer: inward
questions.explanation: Romans 7:22 reveals the believer's inner delight in God's law, referring to the 'inward man' as the renewed spirit.

theological.title: Romans Chapter 7 Quiz - Theological Level
theological.description: Deep biblical theology from Romans Chapter 7 that unites all believers. Explore foundational truths about God, creation, and humanity.

questions.question: According to Romans 7:1, how long does the law have dominion over a person?
questions.correctAnswer: As long as he liveth
questions.explanation: Romans 7:1 explicitly states that the law has dominion over a man as long as he liveth. This reflects the enduring authority of the law over the living person. Similarly, Exodus 20:6 shows God's covenant with those who keep His commandments, and Galatians 3:23-25 discusses being under the law until faith comes.

questions.question: What analogy does Paul use in Romans 7:2-3 to explain the believer's relationship to the law?
questions.correctAnswer: Marriage to a husband
questions.explanation: Paul uses the analogy of a woman bound to her husband by law as long as he lives, but free if he dies (Romans 7:2-3). This illustrates that believers are dead to the law and married to Christ. The analogy parallels the new covenant established in Jeremiah 31:31-34 and the bride of Christ imagery in Ephesians 5:22-33.

questions.question: What does Paul say believers have become to the law by the body of Christ in Romans 7:4?
questions.correctAnswer: Dead
questions.explanation: Romans 7:4 teaches that believers have become dead to the law by the body of Christ, so they may be joined to Him and bear fruit to God. This echoes Jesus' teaching in John 15:5 about bearing fruit in Him and the new life in 2 Corinthians 5:17.

questions.question: According to Romans 7:5, what was the effect of the law on the sinful nature before Christ?
options: It worked in our members to bring forth fruit unto death
questions.correctAnswer: It worked in our members to bring forth fruit unto death
questions.explanation: Romans 7:5 states that the motions of sins, which were by the law, worked in our members to produce fruit leading to death. This emphasizes the law’s role in revealing sin’s deadly power, consistent with Genesis 2:17 on death as consequence, and echoed in James 1:15 about sin bringing death.

questions.question: What is the believer delivered from according to Romans 7:6?
options: The law, that we should serve in newness of spirit
questions.correctAnswer: The law, that we should serve in newness of spirit
questions.explanation: Romans 7:6 teaches believers are delivered from the law, being dead to what held them, so they serve God in newness of spirit rather than the old letter. This aligns with 2 Corinthians 3:6 on the ministry of the Spirit and Ezekiel 36:26 on a new heart.

questions.question: In Romans 7:7, what purpose does Paul say the law served concerning sin?
questions.correctAnswer: To make known sin
questions.explanation: Romans 7:7 states Paul would not have known sin except through the law, for example, lust was identified when the law said 'Thou shalt not covet.' The law reveals sin’s nature, consistent with Psalm 19:7-11 and Galatians 3:19.

questions.question: How does Paul describe sin's activity in Romans 7:8?
options: Sin, taking occasion by the commandment, wrought in me all manner of concupiscence
Sin was powerless without the law
Sin was justified by the law
Sin was alive only with faith
questions.correctAnswer: Sin, taking occasion by the commandment, wrought in me all manner of concupiscence
questions.explanation: Romans 7:8 explains sin uses the commandment as an opportunity to produce covetous desires. This highlights how sin exploits the law to increase its power, echoed in James 1:14-15 and Galatians 5:19-21.

questions.question: What paradox does Paul express in Romans 7:10 regarding the commandment?
options: The commandment ordained to life was found to be unto death
The commandment was easy to keep
questions.correctAnswer: The commandment ordained to life was found to be unto death
questions.explanation: Romans 7:10 reveals the paradox that the commandment, intended to bring life, actually resulted in death because sin used it to produce death. This tension is seen in Ezekiel 18:4 and Matthew 5:17 where the law’s righteous demands expose human failure.

questions.question: According to Romans 7:12, how does Paul describe the law and the commandment?
questions.correctAnswer: Holy, just, and good
questions.explanation: Romans 7:12 affirms the law and commandment are holy, just, and good, highlighting God’s righteous character. This reflects Psalm 119:142 and Deuteronomy 6:25, affirming the moral perfection of God’s law.

questions.question: What does Paul say about the law and sin in Romans 7:13?
options: Sin works death by the commandment to make sin appear exceedingly sinful
The law is responsible for death
The law is weak against sin
Sin is justified by the law
questions.correctAnswer: Sin works death by the commandment to make sin appear exceedingly sinful
questions.explanation: Romans 7:13 explains that sin used the good commandment to produce death so sin might be shown as exceedingly sinful. This demonstrates sin’s deceitfulness as in Genesis 3:6-7 and Hebrews 3:13.

questions.question: How does Paul describe his own nature in relation to the law in Romans 7:14?
questions.correctAnswer: Carnal, sold under sin
questions.explanation: Romans 7:14 declares Paul knows the law is spiritual, but he is carnal, sold under sin, emphasizing human weakness and bondage apart from Christ. This aligns with Jeremiah 17:9 and John 8:34 on the condition of the sinful heart.

questions.question: In Romans 7:15, what conflict does Paul describe about his actions?
options: He does not do what he wants but does what he hates
He is free from the law
questions.correctAnswer: He does not do what he wants but does what he hates
questions.explanation: Romans 7:15 reveals Paul’s inner conflict: he desires to do good but ends up doing what he hates. This struggle illustrates the human condition under sin, as seen in Psalm 51:5 and Ecclesiastes 7:20.

questions.question: What does Paul say is the cause of his sinful actions in Romans 7:17?
questions.correctAnswer: Sin that dwelleth in me
questions.explanation: Romans 7:17 states that it is no longer Paul himself but sin dwelling in him that does the sinful acts, emphasizing the indwelling power of sin. This is consistent with John 8:44 and Galatians 5:17.

questions.question: According to Romans 7:22-23, what two conflicting laws does Paul describe?
options: The law of God in the mind and the law of sin in the members
The law of Moses and the law of Christ
The law of the Spirit and the law of the flesh
The law of love and the law of hate
questions.correctAnswer: The law of God in the mind and the law of sin in the members
questions.explanation: Romans 7:22-23 describes the inner conflict between delighting in God's law inwardly and another law in the members warring against the mind, leading to captivity to sin. This reflects Jeremiah 31:33 and Galatians 5:16-17.

questions.question: What is Paul's cry in Romans 7:24, expressing his desperation?
options: O wretched man that I am! who shall deliver me from the body of this death?
I am strong in the law
questions.correctAnswer: O wretched man that I am! who shall deliver me from the body of this death?
questions.explanation: Romans 7:24 expresses Paul's anguish over the sinful condition and his need for deliverance. This echoes Psalms 40:14 and Isaiah 53:4-6 about human wretchedness and God's salvation.
